title: 5 Minutes That Will Make You Love Jazz Guitar
excerpt: The instrument hasn’t always been a central player in jazz, but the best guitarists have taken up the challenge of finding their own way. Fourteen musicians and writers share their favorites.

title: Blue Note 4000 series - jazz album covers
excerpt:
Album cover design and jazz photography on the Blue Note Records. Notes and 
pictures from the Birka Jazz Archive

title: American Routes Shortcuts: Bessie Smith
excerpt: Bessie Smith, Empress of the Blues, was the first African American superstar, an artist that mingled regal dignity with sensuality. We’ll sample her recorded legacy, talk with critics and hear memories of her contemporaries from the Jazz Age of the 1920s.

title: Excerpt: James Kaplan's '3 Shades of Blue' Chronicling Miles Davis's Record
excerpt: Kind of Blue is the best-selling jazz album of all time. Here's what it was like inside the studio with Miles Davis, John Coltrane, and Bill Evans on the day they laid down one of the record's iconic tracks.

title: Crime Jazz: How Miles Davis, Count Basie & Duke Ellington Created Soundtrac
excerpt: When we think of film noir, we tend to think of a mood best set by a look: shadow and light (mostly shadow), grim but visually rich weather, near-depopulated urban streets.

title: Newly unearthed 1974 session by Clifford Jordan is a striking, one-of-a-kin
excerpt: The tenor sax player came up in Chicago and toured in the '60s with Charles Mingus, Max Roach and Randy Weston. Jordan's forgotten album, Drink Plenty Water, mixes singers with a small ensemble.

title: The Art of Leadership: Lessons from Art Blakey
In a Baltimore basement, a jazz detective strikes gold
excerpt: New recordings of old jazz performances at Baltimore's now-closed Famous Ballroom are being released for the first time.

title: Pianist Robert Glasper and Singer Samara Joy on Making Jazz Now
excerpt: The musicians discuss their recent Grammy wins and why the true tradition of jazz is all about embracing freedom.

title: How a jazz legend's resting place was lost and found, 50 years after his tr
excerpt: Though the trumpeter Lee Morgan was killed in 1972, his legacy was well maintained. At least it seemed so, until one fan discovered last year that Morgan's gravesite seemed to have vanished.

title: Did jazz forget about Oscar Peterson?
excerpt: The visionary pianist influenced everyone from Quincy Jones to Billy Joel, while flying under the fame radar himself. A new documentary tells the unsung hero’s story.

title: Best Jazz Albums of 2021
excerpt: In a year of continued uncertainty, musicians held their colleagues, and listeners, close.

title: "A Great Day In Harlem": Remembering the iconic 1958 photo of legendary musicians
excerpt: 58 musicians showed up for a picture that captured the giants of jazz

title: Is This the Greatest Photo in Jazz History?
excerpt: A quiet Sunday night in 1953. The Dodgers had just won the pennant. J.F.K. and Jacqueline Bouvier had just married. And four titans of bebop came together in a dive bar for a rare jam session.

title: After Six Decades in the Vault, 'Ella at Zardi's' Brings New Shine to Ella
